content:
I presume the greylisting is still in effect?
So the recently advertised position should be boycotted too?
Yeah
God, even the existence of part-time teaching positions is a bad symptom of the root problem. Positions like that should be deported back to the USA where they came from
Of course anyone that needs that job is not in a position to make sacrifices to support the boycott
There's at least one very good person at Leicester who now needs a math job, because they've been kicked out of their research job and won't accept groveling for scraps.
For what it's worth, I've had independent confirmation that Simona Paoli was made redundant. I don't know about any others, yet.
That is the "one very good person" I was talking about.
I reject the jargon "made redundant". She wasn't redundant and wasn't made so. She was kicked out.

Yes, I imagined so, but here and on the categories mailing list no one seemed willing to say her name. I don't think it should be a secret.
I wanted to say "sacked" (maybe that's just an Australian term), but there are legal frameworks around these different terms, at least in systems I'm familiar with (getting sacked/fired is for something you do. Getting made redundant is because of something management does).
Oh, no, I was hoping you were referring to Andy Tonks of whom we already knew. That makes it 2 very good people.

Surely though Leicester university must be aware that this reflects badly on them from the standpoint of trust? If I'm an AI researcher (or a researcher in some other field the university seems so desparate to attract), I'm definetly going to consider my potential job security in light of this thing.

Fawzi Hreiki said:

Surely though Leicester university must be aware that this reflects badly on them from the standpoint of trust? If I'm an AI researcher (or a researcher in some other field the university seems so desparate to attract), I'm definetly going to consider my potential job security in light of this thing.

They probably are, but they will also think it won't matter in the end. One should notice that often these policies are made up by the most stupid people a given institution has to offer.

And an email of Simona was forwarded to the categories list asking people to not say she was fired, for exactly the reason I hint at in my last comment: this term has a particular legal meaning in the UK (and in Australia, too), and it very much doesn't apply here!

In theory, the difference is that "fired" means you're kicked out of your job for doing certain extremely bad things and then somebody else is hired into your job, whereas "made redundant" means that your job itself no longer exists, usually for restructuring/financial reasons. In practice, targeted redunancies are common, for example UCU representatives are being made redundant much more frequently than everyone else. (Which as far as I know is illegal but employers generally get away with it)

This is my understanding of "fired" in American parlance as well. You only say you got "fired" when it's supposedly due to your own screw up. Otherwise you say you got "let go" if it's permanent, and "furloughed" if they could bring you back potentially.

@Joe Moeller FWIW that is not what furloughed means. Furloughed usually means the company is forcing you to have something like forced leave without pay but it's never "if they could bring you back", you don't lose or often it's not the case that you are losing your job when you are furloughed. If the company can't recover after a furloughed period THEN it might move to letting people go.

I do agree that the general terms in the American vernacular is "I was fired" or "I was let go". Although in my experience most people will say "I was let go" while others will say "They were fired" for them

Both the people I live with, my sister and my wife, were furloughed during the pandemic. In my wife's case, she would be off for two weeks, then on for two weeks. In my sister's case, she was off for months. They brought her back briefly when they thought things were getting better, and then it got way worse, and they completely closed indefinitely. She was furloughed until she eventually quit because of moving away. So I think it can be a complicated word.

Yeah although the circumstances of the past year are not standard and a lot of businesses misused the mechanism. I am sorry to hear about your sister and your wife, hope things are better now.

Aside: there is also the "I lost my job"

David Michael Roberts said:

Yes, I imagined so, but here and on the categories mailing list no one seemed willing to say her name. I don't think it should be a secret.
I wanted to say "sacked" (maybe that's just an Australian term), but there are legal frameworks around these different terms, at least in systems I'm familiar with (getting sacked/fired is for something you do. Getting made redundant is because of something management does).

Hmm, I think what we say in the US is that there was a lay-off: the company (in this case the University) has decided that they want a different direction.
There are terms such as constructive dismissal used in the U.K. which include compulsory redundancy. There is discussion of this on U.K. government websites if anyone is interested.
Looks like Simona Paoli ended up at the University of Aberdeen :octopus: I wonder what the Leicester maths department looks like now that the new academic year has rolled around...
That's, at least, good news for the dormant ScotCats group which it occasionally crosses my mind to try to bring back to life
Was it there a ScotCats group? :o

Yes. It ran along the same lines as Scottish Theorem Provers and Scottish Programming Languages Seminar. We lost a bit of momentum when some key energy-inputting people moved away. But now there are new energy-inputting people, so it could be worth another go.
The addition of another important person who is a category theorist but not part of the TCS circuit might be the motivation I need to get out and start pushing

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

I wonder what the Leicester maths department looks like now that the new academic year has rolled around...

It's inappropriate but I'm afraid irresistable to quote Hilbert: "There is no mathematics department in Göttingen"

I'd like to revive this topic in light of the fact that I just received an advert for job positions at the University of Leicester's "School of Computing and Mathematical Sciences" via the Category Theory mailing list, and it includes the quote,

The excellence of the School’s research has been confirmed in the last two national research assessment exercises (in 2008 and 2014). In each exercise, 95% of our research was judged to be of international quality, 65% was judged to be internationally leading, and over 20% of our research outputs world-leading.

I wonder what the result of a 'national research assessment exercise' would be today...
Decades from now they will still be touting their greatness in 2008 and 2014, like a tourist brochure advertising the beauty of Mariupol.
